description.narrative: The project builds on the previous Sida-supported project Gender in Judiciary (2017- 2020) and promotes reforms in the judiciary of Bosnia and Herzegovina with a focus on gender equality. The project is a two-year phasing-out project where the Atlantic Initiative will build on results and lessons learned from previous projects and work to further develop and engage the judiciary to create a vibrant and dynamic learning environment for gender equality. By making the results and changes more sustainable over time, in terms of improved education about gender equality in the judiciary, offering guidance on how the judiciary should deal with sexual harassment and sexual violence, and that cases involving gender-based violence are addressed in a legally secure manner, the project will contribute to gender equality and better addressing gender-based violence in the judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Overall objective: Resources and capacities developed by the Gender and Justice Project are further strengthened, sustained and utilized in gender responsive manner by the BiH judiciary. Outcomes: - Sustainability mechanisms for Gender and Justice project developed and agreed with BiH judicial institutions - Processing of sexual harassment and sexual violence cases in BiH strengthened - Gender biases and prejudices are better recognized and reduced in BiH judiciary taking into consideration intersectionality of gender - With the Gender and Justice program the Atlantic Initiative is transformed into a regional hub for research and trainings in gender equality and gender-based violence.

Projektet bygger vidare på det det tidigare Sida-stödda projektet Gender in Judiciary (2017–2020) och främjar reformer inom Bosniens och Hercegovinas rättsväsende med fokus på jämställdhet. Projektet är ett tvåårigt utfasningsprojekt där Atlantic Initiative ska bygga vidare på resultat och lärdomar från tidigare projekt och verka för att vidareutveckla och engagera rättsväsendet att skapa en levande och dynamisk inlärningsmiljö för jämställdhet. Genom att göra resultat och förändringar mer hållbara över tid i termer av förbättrad utbildning kring jämställdhet inom rättsväsendet, tillhandahållande av vägledning i hur rättsväsendet ska hantera sexuella trakasserier och sexuellt våld, samt att rättsfall som handlar om könsrelaterat våld tas upp på ett rättssäkert sätt, kommer insatsen att bidra till jämställdhet och att könsrelaterat våld bättre omhändertas av rättsväsendet i Bosnien-Hercegovina.

description.narrative: The following results are summarized by the Atlantic Initiative in its final reporting (contribution no 11299, the previous project ) and have been independently verified by the Final evaluation. 1. Domestic violence: visits to courts and critical review of domestic violence judgments The project proposal envisioned 20 smaller courts visits in total - over the two-year project period. In previous reporting period we conducted 17 courts visits reaching more than 220 judges and court staff. In May 2020, one online workshop was organized instead of a court visit, to the Prijedor District Court), while two remaining smaller court visits were not organized due to COVID-19 pandemic The study Gender Bias and Judiciary, which was completed by the Project in 2020, indicates changes in views of respondents concerning sentencing policy in DV cases and elaboration of court decisions 2. Sexual harassment: adjudication of sexual harassment cases and support to advisors. Training curriculum on adjudication of sexual harassment cases that was developed in 2019 and published in 2020 by the Atlantic Initiative, is used as a training material by judges and prosecutors who delivered trainings on the sexual and gender based harassment in June 2020. The training, initially scheduled in April 2020 on was organised online in joint cooperation of entity training centres and was attended by 17 participants - 8 from Federation of BiH and 9 from Republika Srpska. In close cooperation with High Judicial and Prosecutorial Council, the Atlantic Initiative monitors cases of sexual harassment on the regular basis and follows appointments of new advisors. According to Gender Bias and the Judiciary research, which was completed in 2020 as part of the Project, most respondents judicial professionals, 73% said that they were informed about sexual harassment (SH) prevention policies and other anti-discrimination policies in their institutions, while 13% said that they were not. Most respondents said that they were informed through trainings and regular annual meetings in their institutions. Compared to previous research, in 2013, there was a considerable increase in this respect, as 44% had then said that they were informed about pertinent internal policies. Moreover, the same 2020 research indicated a 10% decrease in the number of respondents who said that they witnessed inappropriate jokes and comments in their work environments. 3. Strengthening the responses to non-war-related rape cases Handbook for processing rape cases, which was developed in 2018 by the project as a joint endeavour by judges, academic, NGO received the most positive reviews for its relevance, richness, depth and practical use in justice sector. Within this project phase, the Atlantic Initiative managed to include Handbook related trainings on rape cases into JPTCs regular training programmes for 2020. 4. Consideration of judicial practice in family law cases Family law is an area with many new developments over the past decades, some of which had different implications on women and men, and persons with disabilities, and carried high risk of gender bias (e.g. emerging issues of joint custody of children, same sex partnerships, marriage of persons with disability, adoption by single women, adoption by persons with disability, and so on). The Atlantic Initiative finalised in early 2020 and published in June 2020 Family Law Handbook[1], as one of the first materials on the subject of gender and family law ever published in BiH 5. Research on access to justice for members of the Roma community In June 2020 the Research was finalised with the support of Roma researchers. This research included more than 150 respondents, largely members of the Roma community, but also judicial professionals. The research results in findings related to Roma perceptions of police and judicial work, processing of DV cases, and judges positions regarding members of the Roma community. Recommendations are given to police agencies, judicial institutions and non-governmental organizations working on Roma issues. This research shows that Roma women feel discriminated when compared with the rest of population. The research also implies significantly higher participation of Roma man in public life and communications with institutions in general compared to Roma women
